title: Paschal v. Price
description: This is across-appeal of a workers' compensation award.  The employer, Richard Price, and the S.C. Uninsured Employer's Fund, contend the claimant, Ernest Lee Paschal, was an independent contractor and therefore not eligible to receive workers' compensation benefits.  They also challenge the benefits awarded and contend they were entitled to a new hearing before a different commissioner because of remarks by Paschal's attorney.  In his cross-appeal, Paschal argues the circuit court should have dismissed Price's appeal of the appellate panel's order as untimely.

				Ernest Lee
      Paschal, Respondent/Appellant,

				Clarke W. McCants, III and Amy Patterson Shumpert, both of Aiken

				Ann McCrowey Mickle, of Rock Hill and Thomas Roy Young, Jr., of

THOMAS, J.: Â This
  is a cross-appeal in a workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  The single commissioner
  found the claimant, Respondent-Appellant Ernest Lee Paschal, sustained injuries
  in an accident that arose out of and in the scope of his employment with
  Appellant-Respondent Richard A. Price, d/b/a RAP Financial Services (Price) and
  awarded him compensation at the maximum rate for the year during which the
  accident occurred, plus lifetime medical benefits for permanent and total
  disability.Â  These rulings were affirmed by the appellate panel of the South
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission and the circuit court.Â 
  Appellants-Respondents Price and the S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund[1] appeal (1) the determination that
  Paschal was Priceâ€™s employee rather than an independent contractor, (2) certain
  aspects of the benefits awarded, and (3) the denial of a new hearing before a
  different commissioner because of concerns that remarks by Paschalâ€™s attorney
  may have tainted the proceedings.Â  In his appeal, Paschal alleges Priceâ€™s
  appeal to the circuit court was untimely and, therefore, the court erred by
  allowing it to proceed.Â  We affirm.
FACTS AND
  PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  1987, Price began collection work from his residence.Â  This work led to the
  formation of RAP Financial Services (RAP), a sole proprietorship specializing
  in the recovery of collateral, typically automobiles, for banks and other lienholders.Â  In addition to repossessors (known as â€œdriversâ€), RAP used
  clerks, skip tracers, and other office personnel to work with lenders to
  recover their collateral.Â  Initially, each worker was paid a salary without
  deductions and received a 1099 form at the end of the year.
In 1996
  or 1997, Price organized his drivers into teams.Â  Under the team concept, Price
  paid all the expenses of a recovery as well as designated rates to each team
  member.
Paschal
  first applied to work as a driver with RAP in April 1998, filling out a
  preprinted form entitled â€œApplication for Employment.â€Â  The information Paschal
  provided on the form indicated that he was submitting an application on his own
  behalf and not as a principal of a business, desired work as a â€œrepo man,â€ and
  had previously held two similar positions for which he was compensated â€œper
  car.â€Â  RAP accepted Paschalâ€™s application and assigned him to a team; however,
  Paschal worked as a driver for only a few weeks in 1998. 
In the latter part of 1998, Price was audited by the Internal
  Revenue Service.Â  As a result of the audit, RAP was reorganized so that its
  account representatives, skip tracers, secretaries, and other clerical
  personnel who worked within its office were compensated as employees and had
  taxes withheld from their paychecks.Â  The team concept, however, was abandoned,
  and drivers continued to be compensated as independent contractors.Â  
In January 1999, after Price discontinued the team concept,
  Paschal again began working as a driver for RAP.Â  According to Price and other
  witnesses, Paschal also signed an independent contractor agreement; however,
  Paschal disputed this assertion and neither an original nor a copy of that
  agreement could be produced.Â  Although Price maintained Paschal signed another
  independent contractor agreement on January 4, 2000, only a copy of the
  agreement could be produced at the hearing and Paschalâ€™s position was that the
  duplicate was a forgery.
As they did with other drivers, RAP representatives would fax,
  call, or personally deliver to Paschal information identifying and locating the
  vehicles to be repossessed.Â  In addition, RAP instructed Paschal as to the most
  expedient order in which to take possession of the vehicles that he was
  responsible for recovering.
Usually, RAP would assign accounts to drivers based on the
  geographic location of the collateral to be repossessed.Â  Paschal, however,
  would also handle accounts outside South Carolina and was often referred to as
  the â€œclean-up manâ€ because he would repossess cars that other drivers could not
  find in their respective locations.Â  
Although Paschal initially used his own truck for his work, RAP
  loaned him money for the purchase of additional trucks for his use in the
  repossession business.Â  RAP also provided Paschal with a beeper, a toll-free
  telephone number, a business card, and keys to facilitate access to many of the
  cars being repossessed.Â  Price also allowed Paschal to use vehicles belonging
  to RAP when Paschalâ€™s truck was not operable.Â  Although Paschal paid for fuel
  and maintenance, RAP wrote off the depreciation on the vehicles as a business
  expense.Â  RAP also loaned Paschal interest-free money for the purchase of other
  equipment such as hydraulic lifts and tow packages, paying the providers
  directly and subtracting the reimbursement payments from whatever was due
  Paschal in a given week for the vehicles he had recovered.Â  When Paschal was
  working away from his home, RAP provided financial assistance for gas money and
  lodging.Â  In one instance, Price paid for a bus ticket for Paschal to go to Florida to pick up a car from another repossession facility.
During 2000, the last year he worked as a driver for RAP, Paschal
  was assigned more than six hundred accounts and worked seven days per week,
  averaging two repossessions per day.Â  On an average day, RAP would page Paschal
  eight to ten times to provide instructions and obtain updates from Paschal on
  recovery efforts, even on vehicles he had already repossessed.Â  At times,
  Paschal would return home at eight oâ€™clock in the morning after working all
  night, only to be called an hour later by RAP and told to get up, come to the
  office, get more accounts, and go to work.Â  Price would also call Paschalâ€™s
  motherâ€™s home in Charleston at inappropriate hours looking for Paschal. Â On one
  occasion, after Paschal returned home because he ran out of money, Price became
  angry and instructed Paschal that in the future he was to call RAP to have
  funds sent through Western Union.
The business card provided to Paschal was designed and paid for by
  RAP.Â  It identified Paschal as a â€œfield adjusterâ€ and listed â€œRAP Financial
  Servicesâ€ at the top in bold print.Â  Moreover, RAP directed its staff not to
  mention to debtors that their vehicles were repossessed by independent
  contractors.Â  RAP required Paschal to give this card to the debtor when
  repossessing a vehicle or to leave the card at the debtorâ€™s residence.
RAP ultimately remained responsible to the lienholders for the
  recovery of the collateral and made arrangements for its drivers to store
  vehicles at designated facilities.Â  It also provided Paschal with instructions
  on how to mark the vehicles for identification and required him to complete a
  â€œcondition report,â€ which RAP provided, describing wear and tear on the
  collateral as well as an inventory of the personal items in the car for RAP to
  give to the debtor.
On October 25, 2000, Paschal was severely injured when the
  repossessed vehicle that he was towing blew a right rear tire and began to
  swerve.Â  Paschal lost control of his own vehicle, which turned sideways,
  swerved left into the median, and overturned.Â  Paschal was not wearing a
  seatbelt and was thrown from his vehicle, which landed on him and crushed his
  spinal cord, paralyzing him from the waist down.
On November 15, 2000, less than a month after Paschalâ€™s accident,
  Price applied for a workersâ€™ compensation policy with Joe B. Babb & Co.,
  Inc.Â  In his application, Price indicated he did not use subcontractors.
After the accident, Paschal met with a vocational rehabilitation
  counselor who, with Paschalâ€™s input, set up a plan for his rehabilitation.Â 
  Paschal, however, did not follow through with the plan.Â  In July 2001, Paschal
  worked as a skip tracer for RAP, but that employment lasted only a few weeks.Â 
  On April 4, 2002, during a deposition in a lawsuit unrelated to the present
  litigation, Paschal acknowledged he did not bring a workersâ€™ compensation claim
  for his injury and stated he was self-employed at the time of the accident. 
On June 5, 2002, Paschal commenced this action by filing a Form 50
  with the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Price filed a Form
  51 admitting Paschal was injured in an automobile accident, but denying he was
  an employee.Â  
The matter came before the single commissioner in December 2003
  for three days and in January 2004 for one day.Â  On February 17, 2005, the
  single commissioner issued an order in which he found Paschal was an employee
  of RAP, had become totally disabled from the accident, and was entitled to the
  maximum rate of compensation.Â  Price appealed to the appellate panel of the
  South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission. 
On
  February 1, 2006, the appellate panel issued an order affirming the single
  commissionerâ€™s findings.Â  On Thursday, March 2, 2006, Price mailed his notice
  of appeal to Paschal and the Clerk of Court for Aiken County (Clerk). Â Although the notice, along with the filing
  fee, was timely received on March 3, the Clerk did not clock it in because a
  civil cover sheet was not attached as required by an administrative order
  issued by the South Carolina Supreme Court. Â On or about March 8, the Clerk returned the notice of appeal to Price
  by mail with a form letter indicating a cover sheet was needed. Â Price
  again submitted the notice of appeal with the cover sheet the same day.Â  The Clerk clocked in the notice of appeal
  on March 10, 2006, and assigned a case number to the matter.Â  Price did not send Paschal another copy of the notice
  of appeal with the accompanying cover sheet.
On
  May 10, 2006, Paschal moved to dismiss Priceâ€™s appeal as untimely.Â  The following day, Price moved for a nunc
    pro tunc order designating the filing of the notice of appeal as March 2,
  2006.Â  The motion to dismiss came before the circuit court on May 31, 2006.Â  At
  the hearing, counsel presented arguments on both Paschalâ€™s motion to dismiss
  and Priceâ€™s appeal of the appellate panelâ€™s order.
On October 17, 2006, the circuit court issued an order affirming
  the decision of the appellate panel.Â  Price filed a notice of appeal with this
  Court on November 15, 2006.Â  Thereafter, on November 27, 2006, the circuit
  court issued an order denying Paschalâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  The court later
  denied a motion[2] by Paschal to alter or amend the denial of his motion to dismiss, and Paschal
  filed his notice of cross-appeal with this Court on February 23, 2007.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Appeal of
  Price and S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund
A.Â  Paschalâ€™s
  Status as an Employee
RAP
  first takes issue with the finding that Paschal was its employee rather than an
  independent contractor, arguing the facts of this case favor a contrary
  determination.Â  We, however, hold RAP has not carried its burden to show the
  finding that Paschal was an employee was against the weight of the evidence.
In workersâ€™ compensation law, the existence of an
  employer-employee relationship is a jurisdictional question.Â  Nelson v.
    Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110. 112 (2002).Â Â  If the
  factual issue before the commission involves a jurisdictional question, review
  by the appellate court is governed by the preponderance of the evidence
  standard.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, the appellate court has the power to decide
  the issue of jurisdiction based on its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Kirksey v. Assurance Tire Co., 314 S.C. 43, 45, 443 S.E.2d
  803, 804 (1994).Â  Nevertheless, â€œ[w]hile the appellate court may take its own
  view of the preponderance of evidence on the existence of an employer-employee
  relationship, the final determination of witness credibility is usually reserved to the Appellate
  Panel.â€Â  Hernandez-Zuniga v. Tickle, 374 S.C. 235, 243-44, 647 S.E.2d
  691, 695 (Ct. App. 2007). Â Furthermore, the appellant has the burden to show
  the circuit courtâ€™s finding regarding jurisdiction is against the preponderance
  of the evidence.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 182, 528
  S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000).
The
  determination of whether a claimant qualifies as an employee for workersâ€™
  compensation purposes is â€œa fact-specific determination reached by applying
  certain general principles.â€Â  S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp. Commâ€™n v. Ray Covington
    Realtors, Inc., 318 S.C. 546, 547, 459 S.E.2d 302, 303 (1995).Â  Among these
  principles is â€œSouth Carolinaâ€™s policy to resolve jurisdictional doubts in
  favor of the inclusion of employers and employees under the Workersâ€™
  Compensation Act.â€ Â Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 439, 534 S.E.2d
  700, 703 (2000) (citing Spivey v. D.G. Constr. Co., 321 S.C. 19, 21, 467
  S.E.2d 117, 119 (Ct. App. 1996)).
In determining whether a claimant qualifies as an employee for the
  purpose of eligibility for workersâ€™ compensation benefits, â€œ[t]he general test
  applied is that of control by the employer.â€Â  Young v. Warr, 252 S.C.
  179, 189, 165 S.E.2d 797, 802 (1969).Â  â€œIt is not the actual control then exercised, but whether there
  exists the right and authority to control and direct the particular work or
  undertaking, as to the manner or means of its accomplishment.â€Â  Id. (cited in Nelson, 349 S.C. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113). In
  determining whether an alleged employerâ€™s right of control is such that a
  claimant is an employee rather than an independent contractor, courts have
  looked to four factors:Â  â€œ(1) direct evidence of right to or exercise of
  control, (2) method of payment, (3) furnishing of equipment and (4) right to
  fire.â€Â  Tharpe v. G.E. Moore Co., 254 S.C. 196,
  200, 174 S.E.2d 397, 399 (1970).Â  As to the relative weight to be accorded
  these factors, the supreme court, quoting a leading treatise has stated as
  follows:

	[F]or the most part, any single factor is not merely indicative
  of, but, in practice, virtually proof of, the employment relation; while, in
  the opposite direction, contrary evidence is as to any one factor at best only
  mildly persuasive evidence of contractorship, and sometimes is of almost no
  such force at all.

Dawkins, 341 S.C. at 439, 534 S.E.2d at 703
  (quoting 3 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation
    Law, Â§ 61.04 (2000)).
1.Â  Right of
  Control
Regarding
  the right of control, we agree with Price that the actual exercise of control
  by a principal does not create an employment relationship.Â  Still, direct
  evidence of the exercise of control is recognized as one of the factors to
  which courts have looked to determine whether a claimant is an employee or an
  independent contractor.Â  Tharpe, 254 S.C. at 200, 174 S.E.2d at 399; see
    also 3 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation
      Law, Â§ 61.05[3] (noting that there is often â€œno written or tangible
  document indicating the degree of control reservedâ€ and that â€œ[e]vidence of
  actual control exercised by the employer and submitted to by the employee
  becomes, in such cases, the best indication of what the parties understand the
  employerâ€™s right of control to beâ€).
In affirming the finding of the appellate panel and single
  commissioner that Paschal was an employee of RAP, the circuit court noted the
  following as evidence of RAPâ€™s right to control the manner in which Paschal
  performed his duties:Â  (1) RAP provided comprehensive information to Paschal
  regarding the location of the vehicles he was to repossess; (2) RAP determined
  the most expedient order in which to repossess cars; (3) RAP provided Paschal
  and other drivers with beepers and toll-free numbers in order to maintain
  contact with them; (4) RAP provided keys to its drivers so that they could gain
  entry to the vehicles they were attempting to repossess; (5) RAP required
  Paschal to complete certain forms with updated recovery information that RAP
  would provide to its clients; (6) Price paged Paschal as often as ten times per
  day, often at odd hours, to provide instructions and obtain current information
  on recovery efforts and would become upset when Paschal did not answer a page;
  (7) RAP sent money to Paschal while he was working away from his home â€œin order
  to keep him workingâ€; (8) RAP paid for and designed a business card for Paschal
  to leave with debtors that identified Paschal as a â€œfield adjusterâ€ with the
  title â€œRAP Financial Servicesâ€ listed at the top along with RAPâ€™s telephone
  numbers; (9) RAP gave its drivers specific instructions for completing
  appraisals and inventory reports, taking the recovered property to designated
  locations, and marking repossessed vehicles for identification; (10) Price made
  all the decisions and financial arrangements for the repossessed collateral;
  and (11) RAP, not its drivers, remained responsible for returning repossessed
  vehicles to the respective lienholders.
Although Price has taken issue with the implication of these
  findings, he has not challenged the findings themselves.Â  Admittedly, some of
  these findings are more appropriately viewed as control necessary to obtain an
  appropriate end result.Â  Nonetheless, several of the findings support the
  conclusion reached by the prior tribunals hearing this matter that the control
  exerted by Price and RAP over Paschal exceeded what was necessary to ensure the
  recovery of delinquent collateral.[3]Â 
  Moreover, we cannot ignore Paschalâ€™s informal designation as the â€œclean-upâ€ man,
  which made his position different from that of other drivers in that he had to
  be available for assignments away from home at RAPâ€™s behest; thus, the frequent
  calls from Price and the provision of money to Paschal while he was working
  away from his home were more for the purpose of ensuring his availability for
  such assignments rather than enabling him to complete the assignments
  themselves.
2.Â  Furnishing
  of Equipment
Price
  asserts error in the circuit courtâ€™s finding that â€œRAP provided the vast
  majority of the equipment used by Paschal in the repossession of collateral,â€
  contending that he provided assistance in this regard either because of his
  generous nature or with the understanding that Paschal would reimburse him.Â  We
  do not dispute that a number of the items that the circuit court listed as
  having been provided by RAP to Paschal for his work were either gifts from
  Price or obtained by Paschal with interest-free loans from Price; however, we also
  note RAP provided a number of other items of equipment to Paschal at its own
  expense that did not result from Priceâ€™s largesse.Â  These included a beeper, a toll-free telephone number,
  and transportation expenses.Â  Moreover, consistent with the recognized
  principle that doubts regarding workersâ€™ compensation coverage are to be
  resolved in favor of inclusion, we hold Paschalâ€™s provision of his own
  equipment does not override the control exerted by RAP over the details of his
  work.Â  See Larson, Â§ 61.07[1] (noting the claimantâ€™s
  furnishing of equipment may, if accompanied by other factors, indicate
  independent contractor status, â€œbut in itself it is not necessarily fatal to a
  showing of employment based on other groundsâ€).
3.Â  Method of
  Payment
We agree with the circuit court that RAPâ€™s provision of a 1099
  form rather than a W-2 form is not necessarily determinative of whether Paschal
  was an employee or an independent contractor at the time of his accident.Â  See Nelson, 349 S.C. at 599, 564 S.E.2d at 115 (noting that the method of
  payment weighed in favor of the alleged employer but declining to view this
  factor as dispositive of whether the claimant was an employee).Â  In keeping
  with our standard of review, we also decline to disturb the commissionâ€™s finding
  that RAP set non-negotiable fees that drivers would receive for repossessions.Â 
  Furthermore, consistent with Nelson, we note that, although the method
  of payment in this case may suggest Paschal was an independent contractor
  rather than an employee of RAP, the testimony of Paschal and others that Price
  determined the fee drivers would receive for a repossession suggests some
  degree of control on Priceâ€™s part.Â  See id. (â€œAlthough [the
  method of payment] weighs in favor [of] Yellow Cab, it had some degree of
  control over payment inasmuch as it dictated the amounts Nelson could charge
  fares . . . .â€) (emphasis in original).
4.Â  Right to
  Fire
As required by our standard of review, we accept as valid the
  concerns expressed by the single commissioner and affirmed by the appellate
  panel and the circuit court about the authenticity of a written document that
  Price claimed Paschal had signed and purportedly contained the terms of an
  independent contractor agreement between Paschal and RAP.Â  Furthermore,
  Paschalâ€™s testimony that, on one occasion when he was reluctant to repossess a
  vehicle, Price â€œ[t]old me that I worked for him and that if I did it again I
  would be terminatedâ€ is evidence that Price himself viewed the partiesâ€™
  relationship as one between employer and employee.Â  Finally, although Price
  argued on appeal that â€œit is apparent the relationship between Claimant and
  Price could not be ended until Claimant delivered all vehicles he repossessed
  and Price paid Claimant for those services,â€ he cited no evidentiary support
  for this assertion other than the independent contractor agreement that was
  discredited by the workersâ€™ compensation commission.[4]
B.Â  Paschalâ€™s
  entitlement to lifetime benefits
RAP challenges the finding that Paschal was entitled to lifetime
  benefits, arguing Paschal failed to carry his burden to show his paraplegia
  resulted in permanent and total disability.Â  We disagree.
Under
  section 42-9-10(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007), an employee who
  suffers total disability from a job-related injury is entitled to certain
  specified benefits for a period not exceeding five hundred weeks.Â  The limitation
  of the period to five hundred weeks is waived, however, for â€œany person
  determined to be totally and permanently disabled who as a result of a
  compensable injury is a paraplegic, a quadriplegic, or who has suffered
  physical brain damage.â€Â  Id. Â§ 42-9-10(C).Â  By statute, such a claimant
  â€œshall receive benefits for life.â€Â  Id.Â  As the supreme court has noted,
  the legislature has categorized these injuries as â€œper se disablingâ€
  such that â€œthe claimant need not show a loss of earning capacity.â€Â  Wigfall
    v. Tideland Utils., 354 S.C. 100, 105, 580 S.E.2d 100, 102 (2003).Â  Here,
  it was undisputed that Paschal became a paraplegic as a result of a
  work-related injury; therefore, he did not have to show a loss of earning
  capacity because he was â€œpresumptively totally disabled.â€Â  Id.

C.Â 
  Credibility Findings of Paschal and Price
RAP
  argues the circuit court erred in upholding the single commissionerâ€™s finding
  that Paschal was a more credible witness than was Price.Â  It was largely in
  reliance on this finding that the single commissioner determined the allegation
  that Paschal had signed an independent contractor agreement, a copy of which
  was admitted into evidence, was false.Â  We find no error.
In support of this argument, RAP contends the single commissioner,
  in assessing credibility, failed to give adequate consideration to documents in
  evidence, eyewitness testimony refuting several of Paschalâ€™s statements, and an
  admission by Paschal in a deposition that he considered himself to be self-employed
  when he was working as a driver for RAP.Â  In our view, however, these are not
  sufficient reasons for this Court to deviate from the general rule that â€œ[w]hile
  the appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of evidence on
  the existence of an employer-employee relationship, the final determination of
  witness credibility is usually reserved to
  the Appellate Panel.â€Â  Hernandez-Zuniga, 374 S.C. at 243-44, 647 S.E.2d at
  695. Â The reliability of the documents and witness statements themselves were
  matters of credibility for the appellate panel, which, in upholding the single
  commissionerâ€™s order, discounted the credibility of a number of witnesses
  testifying on behalf of RAP for various reasons, including their demeanor on
  the stand, biases, obvious fallacies in their statements,[5] and their failure to provide adequate
  documentation for their statements.Â  
As to Paschalâ€™s statement during a deposition in a separate
  lawsuit that he had not yet filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim for his
  injuries because he was â€œself-employed,â€ the single commissioner found that, at
  the time of the deposition, Paschal did not understand the difference between
  an employee and an independent contractor and referred to himself as both during
  that deposition.Â  The single commissioner also noted that, in any event, what
  the parties called their relationship would not be dispositive of what that
  relationship was.Â  RAP has not given us any basis to rejct the reasons cited by
  the single commissioner, who was affirmed by both the appellate panel and the
  circuit court, for discounting Paschalâ€™s purported admission that he was an
  independent contractor rather than an employee.
D. Request for
  Criminal Prosecution
RAP
  further maintains the circuit court erred in upholding the single
  commissionerâ€™s decision not to grant a new hearing before a different
  commissioner after counsel for Paschal allegedly tainted the proceedings by
  requesting the single commissioner to refer Price to the South Carolina Attorney
  General for criminal prosecution.Â  RAP argues the request gave Paschal a
  collateral advantage and was a deliberate, calculated, and planned effort to
  intimidate Priceâ€™s testimony and to deter him from asserting a vigorous
  defense.[6]Â 
  We find no reversible error.
Both
  the single commissioner and the circuit court noted the untimeliness of RAPâ€™s
  motion for a new hearing as a reason for denying it,[7] and RAP has not challenged this
  ground in its appellantâ€™s brief.Â  Absent such a challenge, there is no reason
  for us to consider whether RAP was entitled to a new hearing based on its
  allegations that it was intimidated by the threats of criminal prosecution.Â  See Anderson v. Short, 323 S.C. 522, 525, 476 S.E.2d 475, 477
  (1996) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision because the appellant appealed
  only one of the two independent grounds supporting it). 


E.Â  Admissibility of Life Care
  Plan
RAP next takes
  issue with the admission into evidence of a life care plan prepared by Paschalâ€™s expert, arguing the plan was speculative and irrelevant in a workersâ€™
  compensation case because benefits are set by statute.Â  Because, however, we
  have already determined that Paschal is entitled to lifetime medical benefits
  as a matter of law, we hold any error in the admission or consideration of the
  life care plan is harmless.
F.Â  Admission of IRS Agentâ€™s
  Testimony
RAP also alleges
  error in admitting testimony from a retired IRS agent regarding the factors
  used by the IRS to determine whether someone is an employee or an independent
  contractor, complaining the admission of such testimony allowed the record to
  be tainted with IRS standards.Â  From our reading of the orders of the three
  tribunals that have reviewed this matter, however, it is our view that the
  determination that Paschal was an employee of RAP was based on South Carolina workersâ€™ compensation law and was in no way influenced by the IRS criteria.Â 
  Assuming without deciding that the admission of the disputed testimony was
  error, we hold it did not prejudice RAP.
G.Â  Reliance on Sellers
  v. Pinedale Residential Center
RAP also attempts
  to distinguish Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Center, 350 S.C. 183, 564
  S.E.2d 694 (Ct. App. 2002), and contends the circuit court erred in relying on
  this case in determining whether the compensation rate set for Paschal was not
  excessive.Â  We reject this argument.
The employee in Sellers was a teenager who had worked three part-time summer jobs and was rendered a paraplegic
  in a single-car accident.Â  Noting the claimant had aspired to become a master
  electrician like his father and uncles, had a demonstrated work ethic, and had
  already made significant progress toward his career goal, this Court applied
  the â€œexceptional reasonsâ€ rule to provide for progressively higher wages based
  on probable future earnings.[8]Â 
  RAP argues that, in contrast to the employee in Sellers, Paschal was an
  adult who had already selected his trade and was a less deserving claimant in
  terms of his character.
Although the single
  commissioner and the circuit court cited Sellers in their orders, the
  compensation rate for which Paschal was deemed eligible was based on 2000 data
  of his earnings and expenses rather than on his anticipated future earning
  capacity.Â  As such, we hold that, even if reference to Sellers in any of
  the prior orders in this case was incorrect, the error was harmless.
H.Â  Reliance on Form 20
Finally, RAP
  contends the circuit court erred in upholding the single commissionerâ€™s
  reliance on an erroneous Form 20 that was formally withdrawn four months before
  the hearing.Â  According to RAP, the Form 20 was erroneously based on Paschalâ€™s
  gross earnings rather than his net earnings, that is, his gross earnings less
  his expenses.Â  We reject this argument.
The single
  commissioner found Paschalâ€™s compensation rate was $507.34, the same amount
  indicated on the disputed Form 20.Â  In making this finding, the single
  commissioner found that â€œthis result, regardless of the method that is used,
  most accurately reflects Paschalâ€™s earnings and is fair to both Price and
  Paschal.â€ Â The circuit court, in affirming this finding, further noted
  â€œPachalâ€™s average weekly wage and compensation rate was [sic] supported by many
  other documents in the record,â€ and Paschal, in his respondentâ€™s brief, went to
  great lengths to provide supporting figures for this finding.[9]Â 
  Considering that Price has not, in either his appellantâ€™s brief or his reply
  brief, challenged the evidence cited to support the weekly compensation awarded
  to Paschal, we fail to see how the Form 20, even if inaccurate, was prejudicial
  to RAP.
II.Â  Cross-Appeal
As
  we have noted earlier, although Priceâ€™s notice of appeal was timely received by
  the circuit court, the clerk of court returned it without clocking it in
  because it lacked an accompanying civil cover sheet.Â  When counsel returned the
  notice with the cover sheet, it was clocked in after the filing deadline.Â  Paschal
  filed a cross-appeal with this Court, arguing the circuit court should have
  dismissed Priceâ€™s appeal as untimely.Â  Specifically, Paschal
  argues the circuit court erred by finding the civil cover sheet was not required
  to file an appeal from the workersâ€™ compensation commission.Â  We disagree.
On
  March 19, 2004, the South Carolina Supreme Court issued an order (Order) approving
  the use of Civil Cover Sheet, SCCA/234 (3/2004), (Cover Sheet) in the circuit
  courts of the state.Â  The Order stated in pertinent part:

	For the
  purposes of administration, the attached form will be mandatory effective July
  1, 2004, and required with all initial pleadings filed in the court of Common
  Pleas.Â  Prior to the effective date of July 1, 2004, the civil coversheet is
  optional and not required in counties where Alternative Dispute Resolution is
  not mandated.Â  This coversheet should be completed, in its entirety, by the
  attorney filing the action and served on the defendant with the Summons and
  Complaint.Â  This coversheet shall remain as an attachment in order to document
  the nature of the action that is being filed and as proof of payment of the
  filing fee. 

The Cover Sheet itself notes,

	The
  cover sheet and information contained herein neither replaces nor supplements
  the filing and service of pleadings or other papers as required by law.Â  This
  form is required for the use of the Clerk of Court for the purpose of
  docketing.Â  It must be filled out completely, signed, and dated.Â  A copy of
  this cover sheet must be served on the defendant(s) along with the Summons and
  Complaint. 

Aside from providing spaces
  for the caption, case number, and contact information for counsel, the Cover
  Sheet provides checkboxes to indicate â€œNature of Actionâ€ and â€œDocketing
  Information,â€ such as whether a jury trial is demanded.Â  In the â€œNature of
  Actionâ€ section, under the â€œAppealsâ€ subheading, is a â€œWorkerâ€™s Compâ€ checkbox. 
Section
  1-23-380 of the South Carolina Code (2005) sets forth the filing requirements
  for appeals of administrative decisions under the South Carolina Administrative
  Procedures Act prior to July 1, 2006.[10]Â 
  Nowhere in that section or in section 42-17-60, which addresses procedures for
  appealing a workersâ€™ compensation award, is there any mention that a cover
  sheet is necessary when filing an appeal.Â  In keeping
  with the supreme courtâ€™s recent decision in Skinner v. Westinghouse Electric
    Corp., we decline to hold that a cover sheet, which is not required by
  statute, is essential to invoke the appellate jurisdiction of the circuit
  court.Â  See Skinner v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., Op. No. 26560
  (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 3, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 41 at 22, 24) (â€œOur
  jurisprudence confirms that jurisdictional appealability issues are governed by
  statute, and not by the rules of civil procedure.â€). Â 
In their briefs, the parties request this Court to find different
  purposes for the Cover Sheet. Â In
  deciding this question, we find the rules of statutory interpretation
  instructive.Â  When interpreting a statute, all of the language must be read in
  a sense that harmonizes with its subject matter.Â  Thompson ex rel. Harvey v. Cisson Constr. Co., 377 S.C. 137, 157, 659 S.E.2d 171, 181 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  Here,
  the Order clearly states the Cover Sheet is required â€œfor the purposes of
  administration.â€Â  The Order refers to â€œinitial pleadingsâ€ and states the Cover
  Sheet should be served with the Summons and Complaint, the initial pleadings in
  an action.Â  The notion that the Cover Sheet is for administrative purposes only
  is further supported by language in the Order that the Cover Sheet is to be
  used â€œto document the nature of the actionâ€ and â€œas proof of payment of the
  filing fee.â€Â  The Cover Sheet itself declares that it does not â€œsupplement[ ]
  the filing and service of pleadings or other papers.â€Â  In light of this
  language, it is our view that the Cover Sheet is at most a ministerial
  requirement.
In
  addition, the notice of appeal received by the Clerk on March 3, 2006,
  satisfied the applicable requirements of the South Carolina Administrative
  Procedures Act, the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, and the South
  Carolina Appellate Court Rules.Â  Both this Court and the supreme court have
  held clerical errors in the notice of appeal do not destroy an appeal. Â See State v. Scott, 351 S.C. 584, 587, 571 S.E.2d 700, 701 (2002)
  (acknowledging that service of the notice of appeal is a jurisdictional
  requirement, but stating â€œnon-prejudicial clerical errors in the notice are not
  detrimental to the appealâ€); Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 577-78,
  532 S.E.2d 310, 313 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding the incorrect reference in the
  notice of appeal to the motion for reconsideration rather than the final order
  did not deprive this Court of jurisdiction to hear the appeal and noting the
  appellant did attach a copy of the appealed order to the notice); Charleston
    Lumber Co. v. Miller Hous. Corp., 318 S.C. 471, 478, 458 S.E.2d 431, 435
  (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œClerical errors in a notice of appeal do not destroy the
  appeal.â€).Â  We see no reason not to apply these holdings to the present dispute.
Paschal
  further argues the circuit court erred by failing to find it was deprived of
  appellate jurisdiction after the Clerk of Court delayed filing Priceâ€™s notice
  of appeal until after the thirty-day time limit[11] because it did not include a Cover Sheet.Â  We disagree.
We
  are mindful of the fact that â€œ[t]he acts of a
  court with respect to a matter as to which it has no jurisdiction are void.â€ Â State
    v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 107, 572 S.E.2d 309, 312 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Here,
  we are not faced with an issue of subject matter jurisdiction but one of
  appellate jurisdiction.Â  Quite simply, the procedural or administrative rule as
  to the cover sheet does not act to deprive the court of subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  See Skinner, Op. No. 25650 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 3, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 41 at 22, 24)(â€œFailure of a party to comply
  with the procedural requirements for perfecting an appeal may deprive the court
  of appellate jurisdiction over the case, but does not affect the courtâ€™s
  subject matter jurisdiction.â€) (citations omitted).
Paschal
  was timely and properly served when Price sent the notice of appeal on March 2,
  2006; therefore, Paschal had notice of Priceâ€™s appeal. Â Paschal does not allege
  any prejudice from the omission of a Cover Sheet from the notice, nor does he
  assert that he was unaware of Priceâ€™s appeal because of it.Â  We therefore
  reject Paschalâ€™s effort â€œto take advantage of mere clerical error by which [he]
  was in no way prejudiced or misled.â€ Â Charleston Lumber, 318 S.C. at
  478, 458 S.E.2d at 436; see also Parissi v. Telechron, Inc., 349
  U.S. 46, 47 (1955) (holding the inadvertent failure of the appellant to include
  the required filing fee did not vitiate the validity of the otherwise timely
  filed notice of appeal); Scott, 351 S.C. at 587-88, 571 S.E.2d at 702
  (wherein the supreme court held it was â€œnot deprived of subject matter
  jurisdictionâ€ because of the citation of the incorrect county from which the
  appeal was taken); Weatherford, 340 S.C. at 578, 532 S.E.2d at 313
  (holding that â€œ[t]hough [the appellant] did not â€˜technicallyâ€™ appeal from the
  trial courtâ€™s original order by referring to it in the Notice of Appeal,â€ this
  failure did not warrant dismissal of the appeal because the omission was â€œof a
  clerical nature onlyâ€); Miles v. Miles, 303 S.C. 33, 36, 397 S.E.2d 790,
  792 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œThis Court has long recognized an overriding rule which
  says â€˜whatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t matter.â€™â€) (citation
  omitted).Â  
In
  the present case, the Clerk declined to clock and file the notice of appeal for
  reasons that did not affect the substance of the appeal or the notice given to
  Paschal.Â  We recognize that courts of this State have refused to elevate form
  over substance and accordingly affirm the circuit courtâ€™s denial of Paschalâ€™s
  motion to dismiss. Â See Matter of Ferguson, 313 S.C. 120, 124,
  437 S.E.2d 72, 75 (1993) (holding in a judicial misconduct matter that the mere
  fact that the respondent was no longer a judge at the time of the proceedings
  were initiated against him was irrelevant); Gordon v. Busbee, 367 S.C.
  116, 119-21, 623 S.E.2d 857, 859-60 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding the statutory
  requirement that a written statement must be â€œin the form prescribed by ruleâ€
  â€œrefers to the manner or â€˜procedure as determined or governed by regulation,â€™
  not to a specific â€˜document with blanks for the insertion of . . . informationâ€™â€)
  (citation omitted).
CONCLUSION
As to Paschalâ€™s
  cross-appeal, we uphold the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to dismiss Priceâ€™s appeal
  as untimely.Â  As to the merits of Priceâ€™s appeal, we affirm the denial of
  Priceâ€™s request for a new hearing before a different hearing commissioner as
  well as the findings that Paschal was an employee of RAP at the time of his
  injury and was entitled to lifetime benefits at the maximum rate of
  compensation.
AFFIRMED.
PIEPER, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1]Â  The Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund is a party to this
  action because Price did not have workersâ€™ compensation at the time of
  Paschalâ€™s accident.Â  The name â€œPriceâ€ will be used interchangeably to refer to
  Richard Price, RAP Financial Services, the S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund, or any
  combination thereof.
[2] The motion to reconsider and to alter and/or amend
  judgment does not address the circuit courtâ€™s ability to issue a nunc pro
    tunc order in this situation.Â  Indeed, this Court is unable to find any
  signed nunc pro tunc order from the circuit court in the Record on
  Appeal.
[3]Â  We note the â€œIndependent Contractor Agreementâ€ that
  Paschal denied signing requires only that the contractor â€œutilize its best
  effortsâ€ in recovering property and does not have any terms mandating quotas or
  deadlines for taking possession of delinquent collateral or requiring the
  driver be available at the behest of RAP for assignments; therefore, the
  agreement, even if valid, does not necessarily lend itself to supporting a
  finding that RAPâ€™s efforts in furtherance of productivity goals were measures
  to achieve a desired end result.
[4]Â  Moreover,
  although the purported agreement required â€œindependent contractorsâ€ such as
  Paschal to supply proof of both garage liability insurance and their own
  workersâ€™ compensation insurance, Paschal never obtained either form of
  insurance and RAP never asked for proof of coverage.Â  We therefore agree with
  Paschal that the agreement, even if authentic, did not reflect the true
  relationship between the parties.
[5]Â  For example, as the single commissioner noted, one
  witness for RAP â€œadamantly refused to admit that repossession of a car was an
  important part of RAPâ€™s business.â€
[6]Â  In
  her opening statement, counsel for Pascal advised the request for the referral
  for criminal prosecution resulted from concerns that Price had altered
  documents in the case.
[7] When Paschalâ€™s attorney made the request for criminal
  prosecution, counsel for RAP expressed his opposition, characterizing the
  request as a threat to scare Price into settling the case; however, he did not
  move at that time to have the matter heard by another commissioner.
[8]Â  The exceptional reasons rule in Sellers is
  based on section 42-1-40, which provides in pertinent part as follows:

	When for exceptional reasons the foregoing
  [definition of â€œaverage weekly wagesâ€] would be unfair, either to the employer
  or employee, such other method of computing average weekly wages may be
  resorted to as will most nearly approximate the
  amount which the injured employee would be earning were it not for the injury.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  42-1-40 (1985 and Supp. 2007).
[9] In fact, Paschal submitted that, using his figures,
  his weekly compensation rate would be $515.70, which exceeds the rate he was
  awarded.
[10] This statute was amended in 2006 to provide for
  review to an administrative law judge and appeal to this Court.Â  2006 S.C. Acts
  387.
[11] The thirty-day time limit was set forth in section
  1-23-380, which, at the time Price appealed to the circuit court, providedÂ  in
  pertinent part as follows:Â  

	â€œA
  party who has exhausted all administrative remedies available within the agency
  and who is aggrieved by a final decision in a contested case is entitled to
  judicial review under this article, Article 1, and Article 5. . . . Proceedings
  for review are instituted by filing a petition in the circuit court within
  thirty days after the final decision of the agency or, if a rehearing is
  requested, within thirty days after the decision thereon.â€

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (2005).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Samantha
      Gauld, Appellant,
				v.
				Oâ€™Shaugnessy
      Realty Company d/b/a Prudential Carolina Real Estate, Chip Allen, Julie
      Lynch, and Raymond Harris, Defendants,
				Of whom
      Oâ€™Shaugnessy Realty Company d/b/a Prudential Carolina Real Estate, Chip
      Allen, and Julie Lynch are the, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Dorchester County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge 
Opinion No. 4455
Submitted November 5, 2008 â€“ Filed
  November 14, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				R. Clenten Campbell, of Walterboro and Jonathan F. Krell and Alan
  Toporek, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Michael Scarafile, of North Charleston and Michael Scardato, of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

ANDERSON,
  J.: Â Samantha Gauld (Gauld)
  appeals the summary judgment granted in favor of Respondents on her claims for
  breach of contract, breach of contract with a fraudulent act, breach of
  fiduciary duty, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and violation of the
  South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In this case arising from Samantha Gauldâ€™s purchase of 102
  Lucretia Lane in Summerville, she alleged breach of contract, breach of
  contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, breach of fiduciary duty, negligence,
  violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act, and negligent
  misrepresentation against her real estate agent, Julie Lynch (Lynch); the agent
  of the seller, Chip Allen (Allen); and the employer for both, Oâ€™Shaugnessy
  Realty Company d/b/a Prudential Carolina Real Estate (Prudential).Â  
At the hearing for the defendantsâ€™ motion for summary judgment,
  Gauld agreed to dismiss the breach of contract claim against Allen.Â  The
  circuit court expounded in its order, â€œthere is no admissible or credible
  evidence as to the existence or amount of any alleged damage and, as such,
  summary judgment is appropriate as to all Defendants and all causes of action.â€
Over a fifteen year period preceding this action, Gauld purchased,
  refurbished and resold numerous homes across the country.Â Â  In fall of 2002, while
  living in Maine, Gauld became interested in the Charleston market.Â  After
  deciding Charleston was beyond her budget, her search expanded to include the
  Summerville area.Â  Ideally, she sought a historic property suitable as a bed
  and breakfast.Â  If real estate with these characteristics could not be found,
  Gauld had a â€œPlan Bâ€ which entailed â€œa short term investment that I expected to
  make a big profit on in a very short period of time while we continued to look
  for a historic property.â€Â  
Gauld
  made trips from Maine to South Carolina in 2002, 2003, and 2004, and she
  enlisted the services of Lynch, a real estate agent with Prudentialâ€™s Mount Pleasant office.Â  Gauld and her husband routinely reviewed realty websites and
  discovered 102 Lucretia Lane in the Tea Farm subdivision. The owner had
  relocated out of state and hired Allen, an agent with Prudentialâ€™s Summerville
  office, to sell the home.Â  
Gauld
  offered to buy the residence â€œas isâ€ for $400,000, but made the deal contingent
  upon her satisfaction with a home inspection and an appraisal at or above the
  purchase price.Â  After the home inspection and an appraisal valuing the home at
  $420,000, Gauld accepted the property â€œas isâ€ and closed in May 2004.Â  She and
  her husband moved in and made substantial repairs.Â  Gauld testified that,
  within a week of closing, she was approached by a landscaper asking to cut her
  lawn.Â  Through their conversation, she became aware of the proposed extension
  of Phase III of the Berlin G. Myers Parkway along the Sawmill Branch, three
  hundred feet behind the home.Â  According to Allenâ€™s deposition, Phase III has
  been discussed over the last thirty-five years with citizens and environmental
  attorneys resisting its construction.Â  Phases I and II were completed years ago.Â 
  Approximately six months after the closing on 102 Lucretia Lane, a Dorchester County tax referendum passed providing potential funds for road projects.Â  In
  Allenâ€™s estimation, this event made the construction of the road a â€œprobability.â€Â  
Multiple appraisals were conducted on 102 Lucretia Lane valuing it
  at $570,000 in April 2005, $605,000 in May 2005, and $650,000 in January 2006. Â On
  January 4, 2005, Gauld put the property up for sale with an asking price of
  $650,000, which she later increased to $660,000.Â  In June 2005, the house was
  advertised at $660,000, and a listing in the record, dated July 7, 2006,
  features a price of $787,500.Â  When asked why she listed the home at more than
  its appraisal, Gauld explained:

	
		
			A:  
			Again, Iâ€™m not a realtor, but usually when youâ€™re 
			selling real estate, you donâ€™t put the price you want.  You add 
			a little on top.  No one is ever going to offer you what youâ€™re 
			asking, that Iâ€™m aware of.  Secondly, there was some personal 
			property conveyed, and that value was not reflected in here.  
			I, also, in following the local comps, was aware that land right in 
			Tea Farm was selling for - - like, a cluster lot was selling for 
			200,000, and my opinion, my lot, a portion of the price was low in 
			here.  Iâ€™m not an expert, but to me it seemed a little low on 
			the golf course.  I have great views.  Thatâ€™s just my 
			personal opinion.  That means nothing.  Iâ€™m not an 
			appraiser.  
		
	

Although Gauldâ€™s deposition is difficult to follow, it indicates she
  received offers of $650,000, $629,500, and $665,000.Â  Additionally, she averred
  to having been offered $630,000 in a cash deal.Â  In her deposition, Gauld was asked
  about the homeâ€™s worth:

	
		
			Q:
			[Y]ouâ€™ve listed it more than what
  it appraised for throughout the whole thing.Â  You keep listing it at higher
  [than] the appraisal when you know that an appraisal is going to require it be
  reduced?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Maybe, maybe not.  I donâ€™t know that.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Have you examinedâ€”this property now as I understand 
			it, in your estimation, what should it sell for?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Well, thereâ€™s two answers to that question.  
			Thereâ€™s what it should be worth without the parkway.  And if I 
			were to buy into the theory that not only does the parkway not 
			negatively impact this property and yet itâ€™s actually a positive 
			selling point, and if you look at the comps currently in Tea Farm, 
			thereâ€™s a property listed on East Johnson Street at $305 a square 
			foot.  Thereâ€™s a property that just sold right behind mine at 
			160 a square foot.  And say I hypothetically accept that my 
			property is not superior to that on East Johnson at 305 a square, 
			yet I believe itâ€™s definitely superior to the property that just 
			sold on East Shephard at 160 a square foot,
  if you cut that down the middle, my property without the parkway will be would
  over a million dollars, if you do the math.Â  Now, because of the parkway, I
  would never get anywhere near that amount of money.
		
	

Jeffery Wyman, Gauldâ€™s expert witness, opined the house was worth
  a maximum of $650,000. Â Wyman was asked about the increase in property
  values in the neighborhood:

	
		
			Q: 
			Okay.  Do you have an idea of the average 
			annual appreciation for Tea Farm and the Miler Country Club area for 
			the last five years?
 
		
		
			A:
			I didnâ€™t do an appreciation study, per se.  
			But if we look at sales and resales of housesâ€”for example, the Gauld
  house, which is the subject of this, she purchased at 400,000 approximately two
  years ago and at least got an offer of 650 to 665.Â  So youâ€™re talking about 50
  percent over two yearsâ€”45 percent.Â  So itâ€™s probably in the neighborhood of any
  where from 15 to 20 percent average.Â  But, again, the latest statistics I saw
  show the prices going down, people reducing prices to move property.
		
	

When shown the listing for Gauldâ€™s first attempt to sell the house,
  Wyman stated:

	
		
			A: 
			This is 1-4-05.  Okay, this is a listing, 
			sheâ€™s asking $660,000, which is about six months, more or less, 
			after she purchased it. . . .  She listed it in January for 
			apparently $660,000.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			And as far as youâ€™reâ€”within six months of a sale 
			and appraisal, a sale at 400,000 and an appraisal at 420, in your 
			opinion, is that a realistic listing price?
 
		
		
			A: 
			Well, if we made the assumption that the 420 was 
			the market value, my assumption, this would be rather substantialâ€”to 
			me, it would be overpriced at that point.
 
		
		
			Q:
			And thatâ€™s just based upon assuming that it was 
			420?
 
		
		
			A:
			Right.  Again, I didnâ€™t do an appraisal.  
			I didnâ€™t go back and look at the market at that time.  
 
		
		
			Q: 
			Are you aware of any improvements or changes that 
			she made in the property?
 
		
		
			A:  
			Sheâ€”when I interviewed her, she said that she made, 
			I believe $50,000 worth of repairs, to include the pool andâ€”I donâ€™t 
			remember all of them, but she madeâ€”she alluded to me that she made 
			approximately $50,000 worth of repairs.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Even with the 50,000, and if there are repairs on 
			there, is that still high?
 
		
		
			A:
			Again, Iâ€™m not trying to evade your 
			question, but I donâ€™t know what all the repairs were.  I donâ€™t 
			know what the state of the house was when she bought it.  
			Obviously she felt it was worth 400,000, and some appraiser felt 
			like it was worth 420.  Now, you can do a lot of cosmetic work 
			for $50,000.  And cosmetic work, a lot of times people buy the 
			sizzle.  They buy theâ€”but I donâ€™t know that it would get to 
			this level.
 
		
		
			Q: 
			This 660, you donâ€™t think thatâ€”
 
		
		
			A: 
			Right, it would be a stretch.
		
	

Wyman was not asked to appraise other property along the proposed
  parkway nor conduct appraisals considering noise impact or the value of the 102 Lucretia Lane with or without the parkway in place: 

	
		
			Q:
			[M]y question was, you were not
  asked to give a valuation [of what the property was worth with the road or
  without the road]?
 
		
		
			A: 
			No, I didnâ€™t quantify any amount.  Iâ€™m not 
			sure you could.  By making that answer, Iâ€™m not saying that 
			there isnâ€™t a law of diminution in value.  Iâ€™m just not sure 
			how you quantify it.  We like to have comparative sales, but 
			usually on high-end properties like that, youâ€™ve got noise 
			attenuation devices such as sound walls and things like that. 
			
		
	

Allen answered questions concerning his method of valuing homes.Â  At
  his deposition, Allen was asked whether he currently had any homes listed at a
  price he considered to be in excess of ten percent of their actual worth.Â  In
  this context, a discussion arose concerning 106 E. Johnston, the Tea Farm home with
  the higher square footage price Gauld cited in deriving her valuation of her
  home.Â  The property had a current list price of $1.1 million, but in Allenâ€™s
  opinion is was likely worth $950,000.Â  
He explained 106 E. Johnston was built in the 1950s, featured a
  pool, pool house, an additional 1000 feet of unfinished space, a two-acre lot,
  exceptional landscaping with two-hundred year old live oaks, and was completely
  remodeled in 1994 by three professional interior designers. Â Allen called 106
  E. Johnston â€œa very unique property,â€ â€œan extraordinary property,â€ and
  â€œprobably one of the three top houses in the whole Summerville area.â€Â  He based
  his estimated value of $950,000 in part on historic properties in Summerville
  because he believed the home was â€œmore in that category than a typical
  subdivision house, which most of the houses in the Tea Farm are . . . .â€ 
Later in the deposition, Allen was asked his opinion of a fair
  listing price for 102 Lucretia Lane.Â  He replied:

	
		
			A: 
			I would say thatâ€”itâ€™s hard to tell without looking 
			at it, and I havenâ€™t seenâ€”I understand that sheâ€™s done some 
			improvements to it.  But not having seen what the improvements 
			are, I can give you a range, but you know, I wouldâ€”I would say a 
			range might be between five and a quarter and six, somewhere in that 
			range.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Okay.  If youâ€™ll give me second, Iâ€™ll pull out 
			my calculator.  I just want to get a general idea.  That 
			apparently will take forever.  Hang one second here.
 
		
		
			 
			My clientâ€™s house is roughly 4600 square feet; does that sound

. . . 

	
		
			A:
			Or 45.
 
		
		
			Q:
			Yeah, 45.  On the high end of 600,000, and I 
			know that Iâ€™m notâ€”I mean, obviously youâ€™re just giving me some ball

			A:

			â€”for that property.  Are the sales inside Tea

			A:
			I havenâ€™t seen a look at an analysis recently so I 
			donâ€™t know what they are.  Itâ€™sâ€”
 
		
		
			Q:

			A: 
			It sounds about right.  Sounds about right to

			Q:

			A:

			A:

			That is an out of the box listing, and you just cannot compare an

  in the box.Â  If youâ€™d take a look at the house, 300 Elizabeth, 6000 square

			Q:

			A:

			Q:

			A: 
			Iâ€™m not real sure.  I donâ€™t thinkâ€”I donâ€™t

Despite Allenâ€™s insistence that 106 E. Johnston was in a different
  class than the 4500 square foot 102 Lucretia Lane, Gauld entered into the
  record a document titled â€œFair Market Analysis of 102 Lucretia Laneâ€ that
  relied in part on the list price of the $1.1 million home.Â  Specifically, in her calculation, Gauld
  first used the $158.63 per square foot selling price of a nearby home and
  multiplied this number by 4500 to get $713,835.Â  She then multiplied the $305
  per square foot list price of 106 E. Johnson by 4500 to get $1,372,500.Â  By
  adding $713,835 to $1,372,500, she produced a sum of $2,086,335 which she
  divided by 4500.Â  This division produced the number 231.81 which she multiplied
  by 4500 to derive $1,043,145.Â  Gauldâ€™s analysis thus concludes with â€œa Fair
  Market Value of $1,043,145 for 102 Lucretia Lane according to Chip Allen.â€Â 
  (emphasis added).Â  Gauld contends she has suffered diminution in value of $393,145, the difference
  between her expertâ€™s $650,000 appraisal and her â€œFair Market Appraisalâ€ of
  $1,043,145.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn
  appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review
  all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence
  in a light most favorable to appellant, the non-moving party below.â€Â  Bergstrom
    v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 395, 596 S.E.2d 42, 45 (2004)
  (citing Williams v. Chesterfield Lumber Co., 267 S.C. 607, 230 S.E2d 447
  (1976)); Koon v. Fares, 379 S.C. 150, __, 666 S.E.2d 230, 233 (2008); Catawba
    Indian Tribe v. State, 372 S.C. 519, 524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007); Platt
      v. CSX Transp., Inc., 379 S.C. 249, __, 665 S.E.2d 631, 634 (Ct. App. 2008).
  The appellate court will apply the same standard which governs the trial court
  under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine
  issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a
  matter of law. Â Connor Holdings, LLC v. Cousins, 373 S.C. 81, 84, 644
  S.E.2d 58, 60 (2007); Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 633
  S.E.2d 505 (2006); Bradley v. Doe, 374 S.C. 622, 649 S.E.2d 153 (Ct. App. 2007), cert. granted,
  June 12, 2008; see also Higgins v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 326 S.C. 592, 486
  S.E.2d 269 (Ct. App. 1997) (a trial judge considering a motion for summary
  judgment must consider all documents and evidence within the record, including
  pleadings, depositions,
  answers to interrogatories, admissions on file, and affidavits).Â  
â€œIf triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.â€Â  Miller
  v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 219, 616 S.E.2d 722, 729 (Ct. App.
  2005); Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 608 S.E.2d 587 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In determining whether any triable
  issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must
  be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Â Helms
    Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 611 S.E.2d 485 (2005); Med. Univ. of S.C. v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747
  (2004); Hackworth v. Greenville County, 371 S.C. 99, Â 637 S.E.2d 320
  (Ct. App. 2006); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., 363 S.C. 209,
  609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
â€œThe
  purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do
  not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  Hooper v. Ebenezer Senior Svcs.
    & Rehabilitation Ctr., 377 S.C. 217, 226-27, 659 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct.
  App. 2008) (citing Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433,
  438 (2003)); Moore v. Weinberg, 373 S.C. 209, 217, 644 S.E.2d 740, 744
  (Ct. App. 2007); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, 589,
  635 S.E.2d 649, 654 (Ct. App. 2006). Â Summary judgment is a drastic remedy and
  should be cautiously invoked to ensure a litigant is not improperly deprived of
  a trial on disputed factual issues. Hooper, 377 S.C. at 277, 659 S.E.2d
  at 217; Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631,
  644, 594 S.E.2d 455, 462 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361
  S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Summary judgment is
  inappropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is necessary to
  clarify the application of law.Â Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320,
  613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Wogan, 366 S.C. at 591, 623 S.E.2d at 112; Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 542, 608 S.E.2d 440, 447 (Ct.
  App. 2004).
â€œThe
  party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the
  absence of a genuine issue of material fact.â€Â  Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C.
  583, 591, 623 S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing McCall v. State Farm
    Mut. Auto. Ins.Â  Co., 359 S.C. 372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004)); see
      also Singleton v. Sherer, 377 S.C. 185, 197, 659 S.E.2d 196, 203
  (Ct. App. 2008).Â  â€œOnce the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial
  burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case,
  the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the
  pleadings.â€Â  Moore, 373 S.C. at 217, 644 S.E.2d at 744; Regions Bank
    v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The nonmoving
  party must present specific facts showing a genuine issue for trial.Â  SSI
    Med. Srvcs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 497, 392 S.E.2d 789, 792 (1990); Moore, 373 S.C. at 217, 644 S.E.2d at 744; Rife, 363 S.C. at 214, 609 S.E.2d
  at 568. 
â€œ â€˜The plain language of Rule 56(c), SCRCP, mandates the entry of
  summary judgment, after adequate time for discovery against a party who fails
  to make a showing sufficient to establish the existence of an element essential
  to the partyâ€™s case and on which that party will bear the burden of proof at
  trial.â€™ â€Â  Boone v. Sunbelt Newspapers, Inc., 347 S.C. 571, 579, 556
  S.E.2d 732, 736 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Carolina Alliance for Fair
    Employment v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, 337 S.C. 476,
  485, 523 S.E.2d 795, 800 (Ct. App. 1999)); Baughman v. AT&T, 306
  S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991).Â  â€œA complete failure of proof concerning an
  essential element of the non-moving partyâ€™s case necessarily renders all other
  facts immaterial.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
As a general rule, the evidence should allow the court or jury to
  determine the amount of damages with reasonable certainty or accuracy. Whisenant
    v. James Island Corp., 277 S.C. 10, 13, 281 S.E.2d 794, 796 (1981); Piggy  Park Enters. v. Schofield, 251 S.C. 385, 391-92, 162 S.E.2d
  705, 708 (1968).Â  â€œNeither the existence, causation nor amount of damages can
  be left to conjecture, guess or speculation.â€Â  Piggy Park, 251 S.C. at 391, 162 S.E.2d at 708; Baughman, 306 S.C. at 117, 410 S.E.2d at
  546; Gray v. Southern Facilities, Inc., 256 S.C. 558, 570-71, 183 S.E.2d
  438, 444 (1971).

	While proof, with mathematical certainty,
  of the amount of loss or damage is not required, in order for damages to be
  recoverable the evidence should be such as to enable the court or jury to
  determine the amount thereof with reasonable certainty or accuracy.Â  Neither
  the existence, causation nor amount of damages can be left to conjecture,
  guess, or speculation.

Baughman, 306 S.C. at 116, 410 S.E.2d at 546; see
  also Whisenant, 277 S.C. at 13, 281 S.E.2d at 796; Armstrong v.
    Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 225-26, 621 S.E.2d 368, 379 (Ct. App. 2005); Proctor
      v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtâ€™l Control, 368 S.C. 279, 317, 628 S.E.2d 496,
  516 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  â€œ â€˜[I]t had been held sufficient if a reasonable basis of
  computation is afforded, even though the result may be only approximate, or to
  adduce evidence which is the best the case is susceptible of under the
  circumstances and which will permit a reasonably close estimate of the loss.â€™
  â€Â Â  Proctor, 368 S.C. at 317, 628 S.E.2d at 517 (quoting 25A C.J.S. Damages Â§162(2)).
â€œAs a general principle, a landowner who is familiar with her
  property and its value, is allowed to give her estimate as to the value of the
  land and damage thereto, even though she is not an expert.â€Â  Bowers v.
    Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 92, 561 S.E.2d 610, 614 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Seaboard
      Coast Line R.R. v. Harrelson, 262 S.C. 43, 202 S.E.2d 4 (1974)); see
        also Waites v. S.C. Windstorm & Hail Underwriting Assoc., 279
  S.C. 362, 366, 307 S.E.2d 223, 225 (1983); Lewis v. S.C. State Hwy. Depâ€™t,
  278 S.C. 170, 173, 293 S.E.2d 4, 5 (1982); Whisenant at id.; S.C. State Highway Depâ€™t v. Wilson, 254 S.C. 360, 175 S.E.2d 391 (1970); Hawkins
    v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 493 S.E.2d 875 (Ct. App. 1997); Cooper
      v. Cooper, 289 S.C. 377, 346 S.E.2d 326 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
In Rogers v. Rogers, 280 S.C. 205, 311 S.E.2d 743 (Ct. App. 1984), this court ruled a property owner was competent to estimate his propertyâ€™s
  value as a matter of law.Â  Id. at 209, 311 S.E.2d 746.Â  However:

	Where it appears that the owner does not know the value of
  property, there is a division in the authorities.Â  Some courts hold that his
  opinion as to value is not admissible, while others have concluded that such
  lack of knowledge goes to the weight, but not to the competency, of his
  testimony.Â  
	Any exception to the general rule of
  admissibility should be, and apparently has been, applied only in extreme
  cases.Â  Unless the landownerâ€™s want of qualification is so complete that his
  testimony is entirely worthless, it is for the jury to assess the value of his
  opinion.

Harrelson, 262 S.C. at 46, 202 S.E.2d at 5 (citations
  omitted); Mali v. Odom, 295 S.C. 78, 83, 367 S.E.2d 166, 169 (Ct. App.
  1988).
â€œBald
  allegations of diminution in property value are insufficient to create a
  genuine issue of fact regarding damages absent any competent evidence showing
  the existence, amount, or causation of damages.â€Â  Clark v. Greenville
    County, 313 S.C. 205, 208, 437 S.E.2d 117, 118 (1993) (citing Baughman,
  306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537).Â  In Baughman, property owners alleged, inter alia, their property was damaged by pollution from a refinery.Â  The
  plaintiffs simply asserted in their answers and depositions that pollution had
  caused diminution in their property values.Â  In agreeing the evidence amounted
  to â€œbald allegations,â€ our supreme court averred:

	There is a total absence of any competent evidence showing the
  existence or the amount of damage to property, or that any such damage was
  proximately caused by the acts of [respondents].Â  Accordingly, we affirm trial
  courtâ€™s grant of partial summary judgment on Plaintiffsâ€™ claims for property
  damages.

Id. at 117, 410 S.E.2d at 546.Â  
In an
  appeal from a Family Court decision, this court refused the wifeâ€™s valuation of
  a marital home that she admitted was â€œ â€˜a guesstimate based on just some
  conversation I had with Prudential Company.Â  But, they would not, again, give
  me a firm answer.â€™ â€Â  Bowers, 349 S.C. at 92, 561 S.E.2d at 614.Â  Her
  value was determined to be based not on her personal knowledge regarding the
  homeâ€™s true value but was â€œbottomed and premised entirely upon the unsupported
  and unsubstantiated advice of an unknown third party.â€Â  Id. at 93, 561
  S.E.2d at 614.Â  Consequently, the wifeâ€™s valuation was speculative and not
  supported by evidence.Â  
In contrariety, a property ownerâ€™s opinion of his commercial
  property was within the bounds of proper testimony when it was based on
  comparable land.Â  Hawkins v. Greenwood Development Corp., 328 S.C. 585,
  493 S.E.2d 875 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Hawkins initiated an action for breach of
  contract after an intersection that was to be located on his land was rendered
  impossible by road formation.Â  He testified land at the corners of a nearby
  major intersection sold for $450,000 per acre, thus the land on each corner of
  the proposed intersection on his property would be worth $2,000,000.Â  Id. at 597, 493 S.E.2d at 881. Â Unlike Gauld, Hawkins â€œbased his opinion on the
  damages sustained to his property on his knowledge of similar nearby
  parcels.â€Â  Id. at 599, 493 S.E.2d at 882 (emphasis added).Â  See also Hill v. City of Hanahan, 281 S.C. 527, 316 S.E.2d 681 (Ct. App. 1984) (in
  inverse condemnation case, a property ownerâ€™s testimony that she was
  knowledgeable about real property values in her neighborhood and believed her
  property to be worth $75,000 was admissible evidence).
Given Gauldâ€™s involvement with 102 Lucretia Lane and her
  experience in real estate, she is familiar with her property and competent to
  testify to its value.Â  Nevertheless, she has offered a computation of
  diminution in value that is completely devoid of any rational basis.Â  Although
  she argues she has â€œnot pulled a random number out of the sky,â€ she inexplicably
  anchored her proposed damages in part on the list price of dissimilar property raised
  by Allen in a context unrelated to either 102 Lucretia Lane or the parkway.Â  
Gauld admitted both property values she relied upon to calculate
  diminution in value are based on homes which are not comparable to her own.Â  Her
  reasoning that, because she considers 102 Lucretia Lane to be superior to one
  property and inferior to another, one can calculate her homeâ€™s value without
  the parkway simply by manipulating the numbers and â€œsplit[ing] it down the
  middleâ€ is absurdly speculative if not disingenuous.Â  Despite her expertâ€™s
  admonition that he did not appraise the home considering the impact of the
  Phase III extension, Gauld insinuates his appraisal of $650,000 represented the
  homeâ€™s value as affected by the prospective road.Â  With her misplaced reliance
  on the sale and list prices of non-comparable properties, Gauldâ€™s attempt to
  avoid the appearance of making a â€œbald allegationâ€ fails.
Viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to Gauld, all
  appraisals and offers received on 102 Lucretia Lane indicate the property
  appreciated after its purchase and refurbishing.Â  There being nothing to take
  Gauldâ€™s diminution of value calculation out of the realm of pure conjecture, we
  hold the circuit court properly concluded there was no competent, admissible
  evidence of the existence or amount of damages, an element common to all her
  claims.Â  Accordingly, we need not address Gauldâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â  See Wilson v. Moseley,
  327 S.C. 144, 147, 488 S.E.2d 862, 864 (1997) (holding when an appellate court
  affirms the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on a dispositive ground,
  the appellate court need not address the remaining issues on appeal); Fuller-Ahrens
    Pâ€™ship v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 311 S.C. 177, 182, 427
  S.E.2d 920, 923 (Ct. App. 1993) (declining to discuss the circuit courtâ€™s grant
  of summary judgment on additional grounds, including res judicata, where
  summary judgment was being affirmed for other reasons and on different grounds); Ringer v. Graham, 286 S.C. 14, 20, 331 S.E.2d 373, 377 (Ct. App. 1985) (determining discussion of remaining issues was unnecessary after reversing
  a directed verdict).Â  
CONCLUSION
The circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on all Gauldâ€™s
  claims is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

In The Court of Appeals

      Will of William M. Brailsford, Deceased, and Kelly T. Brailsford, an
